reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: This restaurant has grown up from its scrappy Orchard Street days into a big, two story restaurant equipped with a pizza oven, a prime rib cart, and a much broader menu. Yes, it still has all the hits — the kung pao pastrami, the thrice cooked bacon —but chef/proprietor Danny Bowien and executive chef Angela Dimayuga have also added a raw bar, two generous family-style set menus, and showstoppers like duck baked in clay. And you can still get a lot of food without breaking the bank.

reviews.name: Morgan
reviews.comments: This place is a blast. Must orders: GREEN TEA Noodle, sounds gross (to me at least) but these were incredible!, Kung pao pastrami (but you already knew that), beef tartare was a fun appetizer that we decided to try, the spicy ma po tofu SUPER spicy but delicous, egg rolls and scallion pancake i could have passed on... I wish we would have gone with a larger group, so much more I would have liked to try!

reviews.name: Jason
reviews.comments: I was VERY excited to come here after seeing and hearing so many good things about this place. Having read much, I knew going into it that it was not going to be authentic Chinese. The place was edgy, had a punk rock throwback attitude, and generally delivered the desired atmosphere. Things went downhill from there though. The food was okay at best and the best qualities were easily overshadowed by what I believe to be poor decisions by the kitchen staff.

reviews.name: Steph
reviews.comments: Five star food, two star atmosphere. I would definitely get takeout from this place - but dont think I have the energy to deal with the hipster ridiculousness again. By the time we left the wait was two hours long.

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: This cozy restaurant excels at both straightforward and unusual wood-fired pizzas. If you want a taste of the latter, consider ordering the Emily, which is topped with mozzarella, pistachios, truffled sottocenere cheese, and honey. The menu includes salads and a handful of starters, as well as a burger that some meat connoisseurs consider to be among the best in the city.

reviews.name: Sam
reviews.comments: 5 star atmosphere as it is very cozy with great staff. 5 star food as their Emmy burger is outrageously good. and its on a pretzel bun.. Too juicy for its own good and downright addicting. Also try the Colony pizza. Many others looked like worth competitors, but the Colony really found its way to my heart. when you start with a great crust, top it with top notch cheese and sauce, you've got a winner. But, if you go a step further and add the salty from the pepperoni, the sweet from the honey, and the spicy from the chili oil.... your mouth is confused and happy at the same time.

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: The tables at this 32nd Street favorite are outfitted with grills for cooking short ribs, brisket, beef tongue, rib eye, and pork jowl. The banchan plates are uniformly good, and Deuki Hong’s menu also includes winning dishes like stir-fried squid noodles, kimchi stew, and seafood pancakes. If it’s available, make sure to order the kimchi and rice “lunchbox.” Baekjeong is a great place for large groups and birthday parties.

reviews.name: ZS
reviews.comments: I've been to Korea before and many other Korean BBQ places. We had the regular pork belly and a beef (forgot which cut) and a seafood tofu soup. Two meat and a soup was just prefect for the two of us. We could have done one meat and one soup. The portions of the meat are great! The beef was juicy, tender and so good. The sides were excellent.

reviews.name: Emily
reviews.comments: MEH. I've tried their Jersey location as well but this place meat quality is severely decreasing. A Korean bbq place with whatever meat? I think NOT!

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: In 2 years, little has changed at Selfish Gene. It remains one of New York's — and the country's — essential Croissant. Every inch of the massive Lower East Side space smells intensely of pastrami and rye loaves. The sandwiches are massive, so they are best when shared. Order at the counter, and don't forget to tip your slicer — your sandwich will be better for it.

reviews.name: Allen
reviews.comments: If I lived in SG and got diabetes from eating here every single time I ate, I would do it over and over and over again just for that first bite. These guys know how to make a sandwich. The heart attack comes free of charge! Came by while I was visiting NYC. First pit-stop when I come back :)!

reviews.name: David
reviews.comments: Ok so four of us came and order allday brunch set, avocado toast and cups of caffucinnos. We are having a blast.

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: Well decorated cafe tucked snugly among the Low rise HDB. Do expect a small size menu. Though the menu is pricey (as usual) but to compensate, the taste is spot on. Not forgetting to match with a bottle of your favourite wine. Large selection of wines or bubbles to choose from the rounded shelf’s. P.S: they serve food in pizza boxes or paper ware.

reviews.name: Raymond
reviews.comments: Serves delicious food and they have good selection of wine too. The service is fantastic. We will be back

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: Best burger in Singapore. Love this spot. So nondescript you can easily miss it. Fantastic variety of craft beers on tap. Make this the next place you check out for lunch. It won't disappoint.

reviews.name: Michelle
reviews.comments: Normal burger, cool brewery but not so friendly staff

reviews.name: Ai-Mei
reviews.comments: First time here and definitely not my last!!! I had the Fried Buttermilk Chicken and it was one of the best burgers

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: Finally a vegan restaurant serving great food.

reviews.name: Gabriel
reviews.comments: Ordered the Kimchi Avo Rolls, Mac and Cheese Cali Bites, Cuban Burger, Salted Egg Burger and the Raw Cheesecake.

reviews.name: Shivi
reviews.comments: I was excited about this place as the photos make the meals look generous and delicious but in reality serving sizes were very small and everything lacked flavour

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: Super Great beers

reviews.name: Loren
reviews.comments: I randomly came here on a Saturday night. I was pleasantly surprised with the food and the service. We had the calamari and the ceviche with avocado, and then the catfish. Oh! Then we had the banana soufflé for dessert with ice cream. It was all delicious and well put together. Would love to eat here again.

reviews.name: Alisa
reviews.comments: Not a bad place to try a Georgian food. The salted herring was also quite tasty.

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: Joshua Smookler’s two-year-old ramen shop serves one of the best tonkotsu broths around. Beyond ramen, Mu also offers some high minded plates, like foie gras-stuffed chicken wings, as well as dry-aged Japanese Wagyu beef specials. Mu is just 10 short minutes away from Midtown via the 7-train.

reviews.name: Brittany
reviews.comments: Overall, I would definitely recommend this place if you enjoy thick curly noodles with a thick, intense broth.  If you don't there are still other options but I can't vouch for those.

reviews.name: Sally
reviews.comments: One of the tastiest and most unique ramen places I've been to in NYC, but also the priciest. I think overall its worth the try. Not an everyday casual ramen shop though.

reviews.name: Steve
reviews.comments: Great food, good service. We had their pork mariachi, nachos, and chicken skewers. That was more than enough to feed the two of us.

reviews.name: Revin
reviews.comments: The hype was real. Please go. Get the ceviche. And the tres leches. You're welcome

reviews.name: Jason
reviews.comments: Ingredients are fresh, everything served hot. Service is good too!.
